title: Imaginary Friend by Stephen Chbosky review: a bone-chiller perfect for Hallowe'en
text:
The best horror fiction gives readers the heebie-jeebies in two distinct ways. There is the squirm-inducing terror of ghoulies and ghosties and long-legged beasties, which evaporates once the book is shut, like a nightmare on waking. But there is also the more insidious fear brought on by the realisation that the supernatural nasties are metaphors for the darker aspects of human nature.

This is the case with Stephen Chbosky’s new novel. It clearly owes a huge debt to Stephen King, who has long employed vampires and shape-shifting killer clowns to embody the sinister undercurrents of small-town life.

Chbosky is best-known for his 1999 debut novel The Perks of Being a Wallflower, a true classic...
